one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. From the past week's study, what made the most significant impact to you in the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read 2 Samuel 1.
David grieved Saul's and Jonathan's deaths.

questions.questionText: 3. How did the man's report of Saul's death compare with the actual events? Why might he have changed the story? (See 1 Samuel 31:1-7.)
4. Why was David unwilling to celebrate Saul's death? What does that say about David's relationship with and beliefs about God?
5. What does David's response to the news reveal about him? Which qualities will you ask God to grow in you?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read 2 Samuel 2:1-3:5.
David's and Saul's men battled over who would be Israel's next king.

questions.questionText: 6. What decision did David face? How did David decide what to do next? (See 1 Samuel 16:12-13 and 2 Samuel 2:1-3.)
7. Did Abner's actions make the situation better or worse between David's and Saul's men? Why?
8. What reminders, warnings or examples do you see in this passage? How could you apply them to your life?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 3:6-29.
Abner shifted his loyalty to David and was killed.

questions.questionText: 9. What prompted Abner's change in loyalty? How did Abner demonstrate his loyalty to David?
10. What do you learn from the differences in how David and Joab responded to Abner? How do you respond to those who have hurt or harmed you?
11. How do you see God working to establish David as king, in the good and hard times?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read 2 Samuel 4:1-12.
David ordered the execution of Ish-Bosheth's murderers.

questions.questionText: 12. What were Saul's men hoping to gain by killing Ish-Bosheth? What were the consequences?
13. How do you see people engaging in self-promotion today? Which are most tempting to you?
14. What do you learn about choices and consequences from this passage?
15. Through this week's lesson, how is God challenging your view of the purpose of struggles or to remain patient instead of taking matters into your own hands?
